_exec_summary.SummaryText:
See Attached File
Facility Name: Global Ethanol Services, LLC

Blissfield, MI 48228

Parent Company: 

RMP Facility ID: 

Submission Receipt Date: January 2007

 

RMP Executive Summary below:

 

Global Ethanol Services, LLC will operate an ethanol fuel production plant 

located in Blissfield, in Lenawee County, Michigan.  As a requirement of the 

Clean Air Act Amendments 112(r) Accidental Release of Hazardous Air 

Substances program, Global Ethanol Services completed a risk management plan 

(RMP) for any chemical stored on-site that will be above the reporting 

threshold of 10,000 pounds.  This information is considered to be public 

knowledge and can be accessed through the Environmental Protection Agency 

website at  http://www.epa.gov/enviro/index_java.html.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Global Ethanol Services is committed to the protection of its employees, the 

greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the 

ethanol fuel production process, specifically aqueous ammonia. The aqueous 

ammonia is used for pH control directly in the process feed mixture to 

fermentation.   It is the policy of Global Ethanol Services to comply with 

all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  In the event of an emergency, 

including an accidental release of aqueous ammonia, it is the policy of 

Global Ethanol Services to notify the Blissfield Police & Fire Department 

and/or Riga Township Police & Fire Department and/or Lenawee County Sheriff 

Department and evacuate all employees at the facility.  



Regulated Substances Handled



The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn and a process by-product 

known as dry distillers' grain with solubles, which is used as a livestock 

feed.  Aqueous ammonia (30% NH3) is stored on-site and used in the ethanol 

production process for pH control.  The maximum aqueous ammonia stored will 

be 263,829 pounds (35,107 gallons).  



Worst-Case Scena

rios



The worst-case scenario defined by RMP Guidance is a release of the full 

contents of the tank instantaneously during the most stable atmospheric 

conditions, which would be a very unrealistic scenario.  This scenario would 

be a puncture of the aqueous ammonia tank, draining into a diked area inside 

a building.  According to RMP*Comp, a software tool developed by the U.S. 

National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for use in performing off-

site consequence analysis, the maximum estimated distance from the facility's 

center to the endpoint is 0.1 mile.  There are 0 estimated human receptors 

within the 0.1-mile radius of the plant.  The analysis assumed a release of 

263,829 pounds of aqueous ammonia (the entire contents of the tank), a wind 

speed of 3.4 miles per hour and an air temperature of 77 degrees F.  This 

assumed there are mitigating measures in place.  This facility is in 

operation 24 hours per day, 7 days per week and employees would notice the 

first sign of any small release.    



Alternative Case Releases



No alternative case scenarios were evaluated as this is a Program Level 1 

facility.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program



Through completion of this RMP, Global Ethanol Services has complied with the 

EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68.  Process safety information and 

operations/maintenance procedures are documented on-site.  Periodic functions 

such as process hazard analysis, training, change management and incident 

investigation are conducted on a regular basis.  Audits of the overall RMP 

will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA 

regulations.



Five Year Accident History



Global Ethanol Services is a new facility and does not have a history of 

accidents which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property 

damage, evacuations or in-place sheltering in the last five years.
